So far as I know Lambda School is the only school that uses an industry-specific income share agreement (in the US). You only pay a percentage of income if you are working in the field you studied in.

Yet our rates are already lower (as a 9 month school) than 12 week schools.

1120645420407898112.text:
ISAs are the best instrument ever for covering downside risk.

With improved outcomes in theory you should be able to restructure to cap upside return at a lower rate and give more payment flexibility.

Note: *only* possible in schools with great outcomes.

1120644507643469825.text:
I actually don’t think ISAs are the end financial instrument of vocational schools.

There’s still some more financial engineering to be done. We’re close, but not quite there.

1115708540730011648.text:
The really interesting thing is your decision making process as a school looks like this:

"Should we do x?"

"Will it make the students better?"

"Yes"

"Then obviously yes."

There's almost no cost that wouldn't be justified by making our students better.

1115707500609724416.text:
It's only when everything is working in concert that you can create something truly special: Finance, education, outcomes, and technology.

You've seen the tip of the iceberg, but only the tip.

1115707119699759105.text:
It's pretty rare you have finance people and people that education working together to create a unique product offering. 

To make it work we've had to rethink instructional design from scratch, and had to be financial engineers.

Usually those groups don't talk.

1115706444249047040.text:
Why do we cap the repayment on our ISAs? Because we want students who believe in themselves.

To make it work we have to manage both the finance arm and the education arm. 

If you can make it work you can create better finance terms, drive price down, get better/more students.

1115705562610561024.text:
Here's what few people get about ISAs:

If you don't have good terms, you have negative selection bias, and ISAs won't perform.

To avoid selection bias you need to have both great terms & great outcomes.

If any of that is off it all fails.

1115636129884041216.text:
In the next couple years Lambda School could have an ISA payment cap lower than the upfront cost of code schools today.

Better education, better outcomes, no financial risk, no payment if you’re not hired, and cheaper in literally every scenario.

1097582930228998144.text:
So yes, literally every single Lambda School student is in a small group of 6-8 students with a dedicated, paid mentor.

It costs a fortune, but the results are undeniable, and because our incentives are aligned with our students we’re happy to pay it.

1097582441311625216.text:
* 184 (or 83% of) students who’ve repeated a week firmed up their skills, and haven’t needed to repeat another week again

* Students who take advantage of Flex average higher satisfaction and on receive *higher* ratings in technical and collaboration skills

1097581781971218432.text:
* We’ve had 811 repeat sprints, with an 87% pass rate (5% higher than first attempt totals)

* 221 students who would have been behind, lost, or possibly even dropped from the program altogether are now firmly on the path to their first job

1097581069090533382.text:
Every student is grouped in a very small cohort (6-8) based on the level of learning they should be at, and that group has a single paid mentor all day. They focus on the objectives from a single “sprint” or module until mastery.

It’s expensive as as hell, but the results...

1097580019344277505.text:
We introduced what we call Flex at Lambda School. It’s actually a real-life application of Bloom’s 2 Sigma Problem:

Students with mastery learning and one on one tutoring perform TWO STANDARD DEVIATIONS better than students learning under conventional methodspic.twitter.com/0F9fh30eOo

1097567233834774529.text:
It’s interesting how many people think what makes Lambda School work is branding.

Actually it’s product, a fundamental shift in instructional design, finance, and incredible outcomes across thousands of happy students.

When you have that the brand builds itself.
